awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Single Particle Soot Photometer system optimized to quantify black carbon and iron oxide aerosols
awd_abstract_narration:
This project enables the acquisition of a customized Single Particle Soot Photometer (SP2) instrument coupled with a differential mobility analyzer (DMA) for simultaneous, size-resolved measurements of refractory black carbon (rBC) and iron oxide aerosols. This instrument system will be used in a wide range of atmospheric, snow, ice core, and lake sediment environmental research projects. The primary goal of this project is to develop reliable, relatively high-time-resolution, spatially distributed records of refractory black carbon concentration, flux, and particle mass distribution from lake sediment cores in the eastern Arctic and to use these and existing ice core, charcoal, and other paleoclimate records to develop a quantitative understanding of the history and climate drivers of rBC and biomass burning emissions.

Research that will benefit from acquisition of the customized SP2 and DMA system includes: (1) NSF-funded paleo fire reconstructions in ice and lake sediment cores, (2) radiative forcing and melt changes resulting from deposition of light absorbing particles on seasonal snow covers and the modeling the effects on surface water resources, and (3) atmospheric research such as long-term atmospheric monitoring, characterization of aerosols from vehicle brake and tire wear, and characterization of modern biomass burning aerosols and entrained dust samples.

The system will be housed in DRI’s Trace Chemistry/Ice Core Lab that has hosted a large number of post-doctoral researchers and high school, undergraduate, and graduate students over the past decade.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded the acquisition of a customized Single Particle Soot Photometer (SP2) instrument coupled with a differential mobility analyzer (DMA) to facilitate measurements of refractory black carbon (rBC) in a wide variety of natural archives. The instrument was optimized to be able to quantify iron oxide minerals in addition to rBC, and it has been housed at the Desert Research Institute's Ice Core and Ultratrace Chemistry Lab for the duration of this project. The ability to simultaneously measure both black carbon and iron oxides in the atmosphere and natural archives such as ice cores, sediment cores, and natural waters is important because these light-absorbing particles can influence Earth's radiative balance and also can be used to examine past changes in the environment such as reconstructing past wildfire activity.

During this project, rBC measurements made by this instrument have underpinned ice core studies from Arctic, Antarctic, and alpine glaciers to better understand past biomass burning and associated impacts on radiative forcing over timescales ranging from recent decades to past millennia. rBC measurements in ice have also been interpreted alongside a broad suite of other geochemical tracers to better understand linkages between liquid and gas chemistry in polar ice samples. These projects have been highly collaborative, involving researchers from over six institutions from both the US and abroad. In addition to ice core-related studies, the SP2 has been used to examine how dissolved rBC in freshwater systems such as lakes and streams impact heating dynamics of these natural waters as well as how dissolved rBC in runoff can impact water quality with particular interest on impacts to wildfire-impacted watersheds. Lastly, the SP2 has been used to characterize rBC and iron oxide particle emissions to the atmosphere by different forest fire fuel types by incorporating the instrument into controlled burn chamber experiments.

The SP2 acquired by this funding has been used by six senior researchers, eight early career researchers, six graduate students, and two undergraduate students. It has been used to underpin funded and proposed projects led by early career researchers. To educate the general public, the instrument has been featured in tours of the DRI Ice Core Lab and DRI open house events. The capabilities of the instrument have been demonstrated to other researchers via virtual lab tours, as part of workshops hosted at DRI for other ongoing projects, and at least five visiting researchers from other institutions have used the instrument as part of their research to date.
